4. The five-year accident history:
The Bendix Warehouse has been operated Royal Adhesives & Sealants, LLC since 2016 and from that time to the present, has not had any warehouse employee injuries requiring medical treatment and has not experienced a release of 13228-Aerosol product. 
  
5. The emergency response program:
The Bendix Warehouse plan is written in an Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) format which is intended to respond to contingencies that integrates the requirements of multiple government agencies into one combined document. A contingency can be a spill, release, fire, earthquake, traffic accident, or any other emergency condition that threatens the environment, public safety, employees in a workplace, or other specified subjects; and that would require an emergency response of some kind. The plan is designed to ensure that the facility has the necessary resources available to effectively respond to emergency incidents and is designed and maintained to promote prompt and effective action intended to minimize hazards to human health and/or the environment if an emergency occurs.
Bendix Warehouse personnel are trained and expected to follow their Emergency Action Plan (EAP), in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.38, and the guidelines contained in their Integrated Contingency Plan. If an incidental spill or release of a hazardous material is observed or discovered, Bendix Warehouse employees are trained to stop or control the small spill. If a small (incipient) stage fire is discovered, Bendix Warehouse employees may extinguish the fire providin

g they have had training on portable fire extinguisher use and hazards involved with incipient stage firefighting.  Major incidents or events are beyond employees' training and resources since there are normally only three employees that work in the warehouse each weekday. 
The EAP takes into account that major incidents or events are beyond the three warehouse employees' training and resources. Hence, each emergency action plan are the Standard Operating Guidelines (SOGs) that describe the actions taken by warehouse employees along with the actions taken by external responders, as applicable, to stop, control or mitigate the event while focusing on the Overall Priorities-Life Safety, Incident Stabilization and Property Conservation. The Bendix Warehouse Emergency Action Plans (EAPs) address medical emergency, chemical release, fire, tornado, evacuation, shelter-in-place (external hazardous materials release), utilities outages, earthquake, and security threats. 
Coordinated response actions with outside resources is extremely important and HB Fuller's Environment, Health and Safety Specialist supporting the Bendix Warehouse is a primary member of the St. Joseph County Local Emergency Planning Committee. Since we have only regulated flammable substances and warehouse employees will not be responding to releases to those substances, we have coordinated our response actions with the South Bend Fire Department. A tabletop exercise was held May 15, 2020 to review the Bendix Warehouse Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) with a focus on achieving three objectives (1) Increase awareness and understanding of hazards and the potential impacts of hazards, (2) Clarify roles and responsibilities, and (3) Obtain participant feedback and recommendations for program improvement. These objectives were achieved by focusing on ICP Section 5. 1. Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:  
H.B. Fuller's Worldwide Environment, Health, Safety and Security Policy states they are committed to protecting the environment and the health, safety, and security of our associates, our customers, and the public. All associates are responsible for the successful implementation of this policy as follows:
¿	We implement environmental, health, safety, and security (EHSS) programs that are, at a minimum, in compliance with applicable governmental requirements and internal standards.
¿	These programs are consistent with standard worldwide requirements established and maintained by the H.B. Fuller Worldwide Environment, Health, Safety, and Security (WEHSS) Committee.
¿	We are proactive in addressing unsafe behaviors and conditions.
¿	We are committed to pollution prevention by striving to prevent the release of any pollutant that may cause adverse effects to the environment, minimize the creation of waste, especially hazardous waste, reduce and, where possible, eliminate the EHSS risks to our associates, customers, and the communities in which we operate.
¿	We are committed to continual improvement in our performance through awareness, prevention, and employee involvement in EHSS programs.
¿	We establish EHSS objectives and targets, conduct regular management systems and performance evaluations, and report our performance to our stakeholders.
Policy closes by stating The Operating Committee has the primary responsibility to implement programs that are developed to comply with this policy. And all managers and supervisors shall ensure compliance with this policy within their area of responsibility. 
Bendix Warehouse has implemented and maintains a management system to receive and ship products and materials in a manner that conforms to the Worldwide Environment, Health, Safety and Security Policy by managing operations with the goal of protecting personnel and the community while doing no harm

to the environment. The Bendix Warehouse accidental release prevention and emergency response policies are fully supported by the management of H.B. Fuller. 
  
2. Bendix Warehouse and the regulated substances handled:
The Bendix Warehouse is operated Royal Adhesives & Sealants, LLC which is an indirect, wholly owned subsidiary of H.B. Fuller Company. Since 2016, the Bendix Warehouse serves as a distribution center for its industrial adhesive products. 
The facility is located on a 4.49-acre site and is in an industrial neighborhood on the West side of North Bendix Drive, in the North Western section of the City of South Bend, Indiana.  There is only one occupant and is considered General Warehousing and Storage with the NAICS Code 49311.  
The 4.49-acre site contains approximately 64,500-square foot building that occupies much of the property.  It operates strictly as a chemical warehouse that receives, stores and ships chemicals used to manufacturer solvent and water-based industrial adhesives and sealants, commercial roofing adhesives, mirror mastics and epoxies as well shipping finished products to customers. Bendix Warehouse does not perform any chemical transfer, repackaging or processing operations. It operates five (5) days a week, with occasional overtime on the weekends, and is closed for US holidays. There are seasonal inventory fluctuations, but the three (3) employees normally work a day shift from 8 AM - 4 PM.
The warehouse is being used for the storage of DOT Hazard Materials Class 3-Flammable Liquids (sealants and adhesives) which are normally contained in five-gallon sealed pails on unitized pallets.  
Also, Aerosol cylinders (canisters) containing a DOT Hazardous Materials Class 2.1-Flammable Gas with a NFPA 704-Flammability 4 rating. This product is an adhesive used as a sprayable roofing adhesive and contains approximately 5.7 lbs. of pentane and liquid petroleum gas propellant in a DOT 39 pressurized cylinder. The aerosol is a Clean Air

Act Section 112(r), 40 CFR Part 68 regulated chemical mixture stored above its threshold quantity for pentane in an area of the warehouse identified as Aerosol Storage Area #1. Each cylinder is packed in cardboard packaging, then stored on a plastic sheet-wrapped, unitized pallet containing 36 canisters.  Maximum storage is 168 pallets stored in a three-tier rack system. Maximum total product weight stored in Aerosol Storage Area #1 is approximately 218,000 lbs.  
 
3. The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:
Bendix Warehouse has an aerosol product stored in small DOT-39 pressurized cylinders containing a chemical mixture of more than 1% pentane and LPG propellant with a NFPA 704-Flammability 4 rating. This aerosol quantity stored in the warehouse is more than the threshold amount listed in 40 CFR 68.130, List of Regulated Substances and Threshold Quantities for Accidental Release Prevention.  Hence, Bendix Warehouse is required to develop and maintain a management system that identifies the personnel roles or job titles responsible for maintaining each element of the facility's Risk Management Program (RMP) including documentation, communicate changes, and implement any changes for each RMP element. 
OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) and Hazard Communication regulatory requirements (29 CFR 1910.119(a)(1)(ii) and 1910.1200(c)) apply since the warehouse is a process which involves a listed chemical, pentane, present over threshold reporting values as well as Category 1 flammable gas or a flammable liquid with a flashpoint below 100 °F (37.8 °C) stored under pressure on site in one location, in a quantity of 10,000 pounds (4535.9 kg) or more. Facilities subject to RMP and PSM regulatory requirements are assigned to Prevention Program Level 3 which includes Worst-case analysis, Alternative releases, 5-year accident history, Documented management system, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Oper

esources. Also, the worst-case scenario and alternate case scenarios were reviewed information illustrating impacted areas from releases of a DOT Hazard Class 2.1 (Flammable Gas) aerosol.  Exercise participants represented the South Bend Police Department, South Bend Fire Department, St. Joseph County EMA, South Bend Wastewater Treatment Facility and the St. Joseph County Airport Authority. HB Fuller exercise participants represented the Bendix Warehouse, South Bend Plant, Region and Corporate Office.  Because of the COVID-19 pandemic restrictions, the meeting was held using Cisco WebEx Meeting conferencing platform and personnel attendance was confirmed during the meeting.  

6. Planned changes to improve safety: 
Management continues to seek employee participation with regards to improvements on warehouse operator procedures and training.

ating Procedures, Training, Mechanical Integrity, Incident Investigation, Compliance Audit, Management of Change, Pre-Startup Review, Contractors, Employee Participation, and Hot Work Permits. Also, the facility is required to implement an Emergency Response Program that is coordinated with local responders.  
Process safety information applicable for warehouse operations has been prepared in accordance with regulatory requirements and good engineering practices, including consideration of applicable industrial standards and best practices. Process safety information along with incident history and other applicable data including emergency response exercises with local first responders are all necessary to complete a thorough analysis of warehouse (process) hazards.    
An aerosol release resulting in a fire or explosion is the primary hazard with significant consequences. Warehouse process controls include passive mitigation systems including fire doors and a fire wall that conforms to applicable fire and life safety standards. Active mitigation includes 100% coverage of the warehouse with a ceiling mounted water/foam fire suppression system. Other control measures include cylinder rupture disks, alarms, and procedures. Additional monitoring or detection systems in use include availability of portable vapor/gas detectors and a physical security system that is monitored by a third-party security service. Conformance to fire prevention and life safety codes are extremely important and the South Bend Fire Department completed a Life Safety inspection of the warehouse on 05/18/2020 with no violations noted on their final report. 
A Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) was completed using the Zurich Hazard Analysis methodology along with a What If/Checklist method to identify hazards, determine risk for each hazard identified and develop a register for all changes resulting from the PHA.
